pages.features: GitHub homepage with navigation and search functionality. User interactions: 1. Search repositories: Locate the search input field at the top center of the page (it has placeholder text 'Search or jump to...' or similar). Click inside the search input field. Type a repository name like 'react' and press Enter or click the search icon (magnifying glass icon) on the right side of the input. This will navigate to the search results page. 2. Navigate using top navigation bar: The top navigation bar contains several links. Click on 'Pull requests' link (text button) to view pull requests. Click on 'Issues' link to view issues. Click on 'Marketplace' link to browse GitHub Marketplace. Click on 'Explore' link to discover repositories. 3. Sign in: If not logged in, locate the 'Sign in' button in the top right corner (it's a button with text 'Sign in'). Click it to navigate to the login page. 4. View trending repositories: Scroll down the page to see the 'Explore' section or 'Trending' section. Click on any repository card or link to navigate to that repository's page. 5. Use command palette: Press Ctrl+K (or Cmd+K on Mac) to open the command palette modal. In the modal, type to search for commands, repositories, or navigate to different pages. Press Escape to close the modal.

GitHub search results page. User interactions: 1. Refine search query: Locate the search input field at the top of the page (it shows the current search term). Click inside the input field to edit the search query. Type a new search term like 'typescript' and press Enter. 2. Filter search results: Below the search input, there are filter buttons/tabs. Click on 'Repositories' tab to show only repositories. Click on 'Code' tab to search within code. Click on 'Issues' tab to search issues. Click on 'Pull requests' tab to search pull requests. Click on 'Discussions' tab to search discussions. 3. Apply advanced filters: On the left sidebar, there are filter options. For repositories: Click on 'Language' dropdown to filter by programming language (e.g., select 'TypeScript' from the dropdown). Click on 'Sort' dropdown to change sort order (e.g., 'Most stars', 'Recently updated'). Use checkboxes for additional filters like 'Archived', 'Mirrors', etc. 4. View repository: Click on any repository name (it's a clickable link, usually blue text) in the search results list to navigate to that repository's page. 5. Clear filters: Click the 'Clear' button or 'X' icon next to active filters to remove them.

React repository main page showing code, README, and repository information. User interactions: 1. View repository tabs: Below the repository name and description, there are several tabs. Click on 'Code' tab (default, shows files and folders) to view the repository structure. Click on 'Issues' tab to view all issues. Click on 'Pull requests' tab to view pull requests. Click on 'Actions' tab to view GitHub Actions workflows. Click on 'Projects' tab to view project boards. Click on 'Wiki' tab to view wiki pages. Click on 'Security' tab to view security advisories. Click on 'Insights' tab to view repository analytics. Click on 'Settings' tab (only visible to repository owners) to configure repository settings. 2. Browse code: In the 'Code' tab, you'll see a file browser. Click on any folder name (e.g., 'packages', 'scripts') to expand and view its contents. Click on any file name (e.g., 'package.json', 'README.md') to view the file contents. Use the breadcrumb navigation at the top to navigate back to parent directories. 3. Clone repository: Locate the green 'Code' button near the top right of the page. Click the 'Code' button to open a dropdown modal. In the modal, you'll see options: 'HTTPS', 'SSH', 'GitHub CLI'. Click on the desired tab. For HTTPS, click the 'Copy' icon (clipboard icon) next to the URL to copy it. Alternatively, click 'Download ZIP' button at the bottom of the modal to download the repository as a ZIP file. Click outside the modal or press Escape to close it. 4. Star repository: Locate the 'Star' button (it shows a star icon and current star count) near the top right, next to the 'Code' button. Click the 'Star' button to star the repository. Click it again to unstar. 5. Fork repository: Locate the 'Fork' button (it shows a fork icon and current fork count) next to the 'Star' button. Click the 'Fork' button to open a fork modal. In the modal, select the account or organization where you want to fork (if you have multiple). Click 'Create fork' button to proceed, or click 'Cancel' to close the modal. 6. Watch repository: Click the 'Watch' dropdown button (eye icon) next to 'Fork'. In the dropdown menu, select 'Not watching', 'Watching', 'Releases only', or 'Ignoring'. 7. View branches: Locate the branch selector dropdown (it shows the current branch name, e.g., 'main') near the top left, above the file browser. Click the dropdown to see a list of branches. Type in the search box within the dropdown to filter branches. Click on a branch name to switch to that branch's view. 8. View tags: Click on the branch selector dropdown, then click on 'Tags' tab at the top of the dropdown. This shows all tags/releases. Click on a tag name to view that tag. 9. Search within repository: Locate the search input field with placeholder 'Find a file...' or 'Go to file' (usually has a 'T' keyboard shortcut indicator). Click inside the input or press 'T' key. Type a filename like 'package.json' and press Enter to jump to that file. 10. View README: Scroll down on the main page to see the README.md content rendered as markdown. Click on any links within the README to navigate.

React repository issues list page. User interactions: 1. Filter issues: Locate the filter input field at the top (it may show 'is:issue is:open' or similar). Click inside the input field. You can type filters like 'is:open' to show only open issues, 'is:closed' to show closed issues, 'label:bug' to filter by label, 'author:username' to filter by author. Press Enter to apply filters. 2. Use filter buttons: Below the search input, there are quick filter buttons. Click 'Open' button to show only open issues. Click 'Closed' button to show only closed issues. Click 'Your issues' to show issues assigned to you. Click 'Everything assigned to you' to show all items assigned to you. Click 'Everything mentioning you' to show items mentioning you. 3. Sort issues: Locate the 'Sort' dropdown on the right side of the filter bar. Click the dropdown (it may show 'Newest' or 'Recently updated'). Select an option: 'Newest', 'Oldest', 'Most commented', 'Least commented', 'Recently updated', 'Least recently updated'. 4. View labels: On the left sidebar, there's a 'Labels' section. Click on any label name (e.g., 'bug', 'enhancement', 'good first issue') to filter issues with that label. Click 'Clear' to remove label filters. 5. View milestones: On the left sidebar, there's a 'Milestones' section. Click on a milestone name to filter issues in that milestone. 6. Create new issue: Locate the green 'New issue' button on the right side of the page. Click the 'New issue' button to navigate to the issue creation page. 7. Open an issue: Click on any issue title (it's a clickable link, usually blue text) in the issues list to open that issue's detail page. 8. Use issue templates: If you click 'New issue', you may see issue templates. Click on a template card (e.g., 'Bug report', 'Feature request') to use that template, or click 'Open a blank issue' link at the bottom to create an issue without a template.

React repository pull requests list page. User interactions: 1. Filter pull requests: Locate the filter input field at the top. Click inside the input field. Type filters like 'is:open' for open PRs, 'is:closed' for closed PRs, 'is:merged' for merged PRs, 'author:username' for specific author, 'label:bug' for specific label. Press Enter to apply. 2. Use filter buttons: Below the search input, click 'Open' button to show open PRs. Click 'Closed' button to show closed PRs. Click 'Your pull requests' to show your PRs. 3. Sort pull requests: Click the 'Sort' dropdown on the right (shows options like 'Newest', 'Oldest', 'Most commented'). Select a sort option. 4. View labels: In the left sidebar 'Labels' section, click on a label name to filter PRs with that label. 5. View milestones: In the left sidebar 'Milestones' section, click on a milestone to filter PRs in that milestone. 6. Create new pull request: Click the green 'New pull request' button on the right side. This opens the PR creation page. 7. Open a pull request: Click on any PR title (clickable link) in the list to view the PR detail page. 8. Compare branches: If you click 'New pull request', you'll see a 'Compare' page. Use the 'base:' dropdown to select the base branch (e.g., 'main'). Use the 'compare:' dropdown to select the branch to merge (e.g., 'feature-branch'). GitHub will show the diff and allow you to create the PR.

Create new issue page for React repository. User interactions: 1. Select issue template: If templates are available, you'll see template cards. Click on a template card (e.g., 'Bug report' card with description 'Create a report to help us improve') to use that template. Or click 'Open a blank issue' link at the bottom to create without a template. 2. Fill issue title: Locate the 'Title' input field at the top (it has placeholder 'Title' or 'Issue title'). Click inside the input field. Type a descriptive title like 'Button component does not handle click events correctly'. 3. Fill issue body: Below the title, there's a large textarea for the issue description. If you selected a template, it will have pre-filled sections with markdown. Click inside the textarea. Edit or fill in the template sections. For a bug report template, you might see sections like 'Describe the bug', 'To Reproduce', 'Expected behavior', 'Screenshots', 'Environment'. Fill in each section with relevant information. 4. Use markdown editor: The textarea supports markdown. You can type markdown syntax like **bold**, *italic*, `code`, [links](url). There are formatting buttons above the textarea: click 'B' for bold, 'I' for italic, link icon for creating links, etc. 5. Preview markdown: Click the 'Preview' tab above the textarea to see a rendered preview of your markdown. Click 'Write' tab to go back to editing. 6. Add labels: On the right sidebar, locate the 'Labels' section. Click the gear icon or 'Labels' text to open the labels dropdown. In the dropdown, check the checkboxes next to relevant labels (e.g., 'bug', 'enhancement', 'good first issue'). Click outside the dropdown to close it. 7. Assign assignees: In the right sidebar 'Assignees' section, click 'assign yourself' link or the gear icon. In the dropdown, type a username or click on a user from the list to assign them. Click outside to close. 8. Set milestone: In the right sidebar 'Milestone' section, click 'Set milestone' or the gear icon. Select a milestone from the dropdown, or click 'Clear' to remove. 9. Submit issue: Scroll to the bottom. Click the green 'Submit new issue' button to create the issue. Or click 'Cancel' button to discard. 10. Attach files: Click the 'Attach files by dragging & dropping, selecting or pasting them' area at the bottom of the textarea to upload images or files. Drag and drop files, or click to open file picker.

GitHub user profile page (using octocat as example). User interactions: 1. View profile information: At the top, you'll see the user's avatar (profile picture), username, bio, location, website link, and social links. Click on the website link to open it in a new tab. 2. View repositories: Below the profile info, there are tabs. Click 'Repositories' tab (default) to see the user's repositories. The repositories are displayed in a grid or list. Each repository card shows: repository name, description, programming language, star count, fork count, and last updated time. Click on any repository name to navigate to that repository. 3. Filter repositories: Above the repositories list, there's a search input with placeholder 'Find a repository...'. Click inside and type a repository name to filter. Use the 'Type' dropdown to filter by 'All', 'Public', 'Private', 'Sources', 'Forks', 'Archived', 'Mirrors'. Use the 'Language' dropdown to filter by programming language. Use the 'Sort' dropdown to sort by 'Last updated', 'Name', 'Stars'. 4. View stars: Click the 'Stars' tab to see repositories the user has starred. Browse through the starred repositories. Click on a repository name to view it. 5. View followers: Locate the 'Followers' link (shows follower count) below the username. Click 'Followers' to see the list of users following this profile. Click on any user's avatar or username to view their profile. 6. View following: Click the 'Following' link (shows following count) next to 'Followers' to see users this profile follows. 7. View contributions: Scroll down to see the contributions graph (heatmap showing activity by day). Hover over squares in the graph to see contribution details for that day. 8. View pinned repositories: At the top of the repositories section, there may be 'Pinned' repositories. These are highlighted repository cards. Click on any pinned repository to view it. 9. View activity: Click the 'Contribution activity' or activity feed section to see recent activity. Click on activity items to view details. 10. Follow user: If you're logged in and viewing another user's profile, locate the 'Follow' button (or 'Unfollow' if already following) near the top right. Click it to follow or unfollow the user.

persona: You are a developer who wants to contribute to the React open-source project. Your goal is to find a good first issue to work on, understand the codebase structure, and create a pull request. Your approach: First, navigate to the React repository on GitHub. Next, browse the Issues page and filter for 'good first issue' labeled issues. Then, select an issue that interests you and read its description and comments. Finally, explore the repository code structure to understand where you need to make changes, and create a new branch to start working on the fix.
